questions.text: During an individual psychotherapy session, the therapist began talking excessively and confronted the patient. This behaviour likely resulted from something in the patient's actions and their interaction with the therapist. What is this an example of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Countertransference refers to the therapist's emotional and behavioural responses toward the patient, which are influenced by the therapist's own unconscious feelings, personal experiences, and the patient's transference.

  • It involves the therapist's internal reactions-both conscious and unconscious-to the patient.
  • These reactions may be evoked by the patient's transference or by traits and behaviours that unconsciously remind the therapist of someone significant from their past.
  • In this scenario, the therapist's excessive talking and confrontation are likely emotional reactions triggered by the therapeutic interaction, rather than objective clinical responses.

Explanation of other options:

Displacement (Option B): This is when a person shifts emotions (often anger or frustration) from the original source to a safer target (e.g., yelling at a subordinate because of anger toward a boss). It applies to the patient or therapist displacing feelings-but in this scenario, it's not about redirecting emotion, it's about internal emotional reaction of the therapist, so not the best fit.

Projection (Option C): This is when a person attributes their own unacceptable thoughts or feelings to someone else (e.g., a jealous person accusing others of jealousy). There's no evidence here that the therapist is attributing their own feelings to the patient, so this doesn't apply.

Projective identification (Option D): This is a more complex defense mechanism, where someone induces feelings in another person that are then unconsciously experienced and expressed by that person. It could theoretically be involved, but this is more elaborate than what is described. The focus here is on the therapist's emotional response, not on a mutual unconscious dynamic, making countertransference a better fit.

questions.text: According to Freud, during psychosexual development, a boy focuses his love on his mother. This can progress to a stage where he becomes jealous of his father and wishes to kill him. However, he cannot act on this impulse due to fear of castration, leading him to repress these urges and move on to the next developmental stage. Which of the following best describes this aspect of the boy's psychosocial development?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Oedipus complex refers specifically to a boy's unconscious sexual desire for his mother and rivalry with his father, whom he fears will punish him through castration (castration anxiety). This complex is resolved during the phallic stage, through identification with the same-sex parent and repression of incestuous desires.

The term originates from Sophocles' tragedy "Oedipus Rex," in which Oedipus unknowingly kills his father and marries his mother.

Freud's psychosexual stages of development include:

  • Oral phase (0-1 year): Focus on oral activities such as sucking and biting.
  • Anal phase (1-3 years): Focus on bowel and bladder control, related to toilet training. (Option A ruled out)
  • Phallic phase (3-5/6 years): Focus on genitals; this is the stage where the Oedipus complex occurs.
  • Latency phase (5/6 years-puberty): Sexual impulses are repressed; focus shifts to socialisation and learning. (Option C ruled out)
  • Genital phase (puberty onward): Mature sexual interests and capacity for adult relationships develop. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: An 8-month-old girl enjoys picking up toys and bringing them to her mouth. She is often observed sucking on them. According to Freud's theory of psychosexual development, which phase is she currently experiencing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The 8-month-old girl is engaging in sucking and mouthing toys-typical behaviors of the oral stage.

Definition:

The oral stage is the earliest phase of Freud's psychosexual development, where the infant's needs, perceptions, and expressions are primarily centered on the mouth, lips, tongue, and sucking reflex. It begins at birth and typically lasts until about 18 months.

Description:

  • The oral zone dominates the infant's psychic life, serving as the main source of gratification.
  • Oral sensations include:
    • Thirst and hunger
    • Pleasure from sucking and swallowing
    • Comfort from tactile stimulations (e.g., from breastfeeding or bottle-feeding)
  • The oral drive has two components:
    • Libidinal (pleasurable and soothing, e.g., sucking)
    • Aggressive (oral sadism: biting, spitting, chewing, crying)
  • The Oral Triad: Wishes to eat, sleep, and reach relaxation at the end of sucking (often right before sleep).

Objectives of the Oral Stage:

  • Establish trust and a sense of dependency on the caregiver or nursing object.
  • Experience gratification of oral libidinal needs without overwhelming conflict or guilt from oral aggression.
  • Build the foundation for future attachment, self-trust, and interpersonal trust.

Pathological Traits:

Excessive oral gratifications or deprivation can result in libidinal fixations contributing to pathologic traits. Such traits can include

  • Excessive optimism
  • Narcissism
  • Pessimism (as in depressive states)
  • Demandingness
  • Envy and jealousy

Successful Resolution Leads To:

  • Capacity to give to and receive from others in relationships.
  • Ability to rely on others with trust while maintaining self-reliance and self-trust.
  • Development of healthy interpersonal boundaries without excessive dependence or envy.

Overview of Freuds Psychosexual Stages:

  • Oral Phase (0-1 year): Focus on oral activities (sucking, biting, feeding).
  • Anal Phase (1-3 years): Focus on bowel and bladder control; associated with toilet training. (Option A ruled out)
  • Phallic Phase (3-5/6 years): Focus on genitals; emergence of the Oedipus/Electra complex.
  • Latency Phase (5/6 years-puberty): Sexual drives are repressed; focus shifts to learning and social interaction. (Option C ruled out)
  • Genital Phase (Puberty onward): Maturation of sexual interests and establishment of mature sexual relationships. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A girl starts to realise that she is a girl, which is different from being a boy. How old is she likely to be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gender identity is a child's understanding of whether they are male or female.
  • It develops around 2-3 years of age, followed by gender stability (permanence of gender identity) by about 4 years of age.
  • Gender constancy (gender identity unalterable by change in appearance) appears at around 6 years of age.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male lawyer wished for his child to become a lawyer. After the child tragically died in a car accident, the lawyer began offering free legal advice to students. Which is the most likely defence mechanism at play?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this case, a 55-year-old lawyer, after the tragic loss of his child, channels his grief by offering free legal advice to students. This behavior is best explained by altruism, a mature defense mechanism in which an individual constructively helps others in a meaningful way to cope with personal emotional conflict or stress.

Mature defenses:

  • These mechanisms are healthy and adaptive throughout the life cycle.
  • They are socially adaptive and useful in the integration of personal needs and motives, social demands, and interpersonal relations.
  • They can underlie seemingly admirable and virtuous patterns of behavior

Explanation of other options:

Acting out (Option A) involves expressing unconscious feelings through actions rather than words, typically impulsive or disruptive, which doesn't apply here.

Reaction formation (Option D) is seen in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder; here, the attitude is opposed to the oppressed wish and constitutes the opposite reaction.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman had an affair with her neighbour but accused her husband of being unfaithful. What is the most likely defence mechanism at play?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Projection is a defense mechanism in which a person unconsciously attributes their own unacceptable thoughts, impulses, or feelings to someone else.
  • This involves perceiving and reacting to internal impulses as though they originate from outside the self.
  • In this case, the woman, who is herself unfaithful, accuses her husband of infidelity-projecting her own guilt and unacceptable behavior onto him. This helps her avoid confronting her own actions and maintains her psychological balance by shifting blame externally.
  • At more severe levels, projection can lead to delusional beliefs, particularly persecutory ones, where the individual believes others are targeting or harming them.

Explanation of other options:

Acting out (Option A) involves expressing unconscious feelings through actions rather than words, often in a disruptive or impulsive manner.

Rationalisation (Option C) is a way of explaining things more logically and in a socially acceptable way so that the true motive is not perceived. For example, a heavy drinker explains the cardiac advantage of drinking alcohol.

Repression (Option D) is a type of basic defence in which unacceptable or uncomfortable ideas, thoughts or emotions are pushed away into the unconscious.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman saw her boyfriend talking to another girl on the phone and immediately believed that he was cheating on her. What is the most likely cognitive distortion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Arbitrary inference is a type of cognitive distortion in which a person draws a conclusion without sufficient evidence. In this case, the woman assumes her boyfriend is cheating based solely on a phone conversation, without any supporting proof.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male follower of Mahatma Gandhi does not cooperate with extra and unnecessary tasks assigned by his manager. However, he never expresses his anger through shouting or physical aggression. What is the most likely defense mechanism at play?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Passive aggression is the indirect expression of hostility or negative feelings. The aggression is not openly expressed but rather channeled through subtle, resistant, or obstructive behavior.

Core Behavior Traits:

  • Intentional inefficiency, procrastination, stubbornness, or forgetfulness.
  • Non-compliance with demands or expectations, especially from authority figures.
  • Chronic lateness, dawdling, or intentional errors as a way of expressing opposition.
  • Avoidance of direct confrontation, while still expressing hostility through actions.
  • Often accompanied by a mildly sullen, irritable, or pessimistic demeanor.

Psychodynamic Roots:

  • Originates from a conflict between the desire to express aggression and the fear of retaliation or guilt associated with doing so openly.
  • Often stems from childhood environments where direct expression of anger was discouraged or punished.

Clinical Examples:

  • A subordinate agrees to complete a task but deliberately delays it or does it incorrectly.
  • A person frequently "forgets" important dates or tasks to irritate someone while denying any malicious intent.
  • In this question's scenario: The follower of Mahatma Gandhi, who avoids confrontation yet resists unnecessary tasks, is indirectly expressing his displeasure-classic passive-aggressive behavior.

Explanation of other options:

Repression (Option A) is a type of basic defence in which unacceptable or uncomfortable ideas, thoughts or emotions are pushed away into unconsciousness.

Isolation (Option B) refers to separating emotions from thoughts or events (e.g., describing a traumatic event in a detached, unemotional manner).

Regression (Option D) is a return to an earlier stage of psychological development in response to stress (e.g., acting childishly when overwhelmed).

questions.text: A 26-year-old man was harshly scolded by his landlord after being late with rent. That evening, he went home, curled up under a blanket with his childhood teddy bear, and began watching old animated movies from his school days. What is the most likely defence mechanism at play?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sublimation is a mature defence mechanism in which negative emotions or instinctual impulses are channelled into socially acceptable and often productive activities. In this case, the trainee redirects his frustration and anger into vigorous physical exercise, which is both healthy and constructive.

Explanation of other options:

Reaction formation (Option A) involves replacing an unacceptable feeling or impulse with its opposite (e.g., treating someone you dislike with excessive friendliness).

Repression (Option B) refers to unconsciously blocking out distressing thoughts or memories.

Passive aggression (Option D) is the indirect expression of hostility, such as procrastination or stubbornness, rather than direct confrontation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man was harshly scolded by his landlord after being late with rent. That evening, he went home, curled up under a blanket with his childhood teddy bear, and began watching old animated movies from his school days. What is the most likely defence mechanism at play?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Regression is an immature defence mechanism in which a person reverts to behaviours characteristic of an earlier stage of psychological development, especially when under stress.
  • It is often seen in adults returning to childlike behaviours when they feel overwhelmed or threatened.
  • In this scenario, after being emotionally hurt by the confrontation with his landlord, the man subconsciously seeks comfort in childlike actions-cuddling a teddy bear, watching cartoons-behaviours that previously made him feel safe and soothed during childhood.

Defence mechanisms are unconscious psychological strategies used by individuals to cope with reality and maintain self-image by reducing anxiety arising from unacceptable or potentially harmful impulses. They help protect the ego from distress.

Classification of Defense mechanisms:

  1. Narcissistic-Psychotic Defenses:
    • These defenses are usually found as part of a psychotic process, but may also occur in young children and adult dreams or fantasies.
    • They share the common note of avoiding, negating, or distorting reality.
    • Eg. Prejection, denial, distortion
  2. Immature Defenses:
    • These mechanisms are fairly common in preadolescent years and in adult character disorders.
    • They are often mobilized by anxieties related to intimacy or its loss.
    • Although they are regarded as socially awkward and undesirable, they often moderate with improvement in interpersonal relationships or with increased personal maturity.
    • Eg. Acting out, blocking, hypochondriasis, regression, projection
  3. Neurotic Defenses:
    • These are common in apparently normal and healthy individuals as well as in neurotic disorders.
    • They function usually in the alleviation of distressing affects and may be expressed in neurotic forms of behavior.
    • Depending on circumstances, they can also have an adaptive or socially acceptable aspect.
    • Eg. Controlling, dissociation, externalization, inhibition, isolation
  4. Mature Defenses:
    • These mechanisms are healthy and adaptive throughout the life cycle.
    • They are socially adaptive and useful in the integration of personal needs and motives, social demands, and interpersonal relations.
    • They can underlie seemingly admirable and virtuous patterns of behavior.
    • Eg. Altruism, humor, suppression, sublimation, asceticism

Incorrect options explained:

Displacement (Option A) involves shifting emotional responses from the original source to a safer or more acceptable substitute (e.g., yelling at a pet after being scolded by a boss). It is a neurotic defense mechanism

Isolation (Option B) refers to separating emotional responses from thoughts or events to avoid distress, such as describing a traumatic event without emotion. It is a neurotic defense mechanism

Projection (Option C) is attributing one's own unacceptable thoughts, feelings, or impulses to another person. It is an immature defense mechanism

questions.text: Which of the following occurs before the onset of object constancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Object constancy is a developmental milestone from Margaret Mahler's separation-individuation theory.
  • It typically emerges around 2 to 3 years of age and refers to a child's ability to maintain a stable emotional attachment to a caregiver, even when the caregiver is not physically present.
  • Oral phase is a part of Freud's psychosexual stages, and it occurs from birth to around 18 months of age. It precedes the development of object constancy.

Explanation of other options:

Sensorimotor stage (Option A): This is the first stage in Piaget's cognitive development theory, spanning from birth to 2 years. Since object constancy develops toward the end or just after this stage, it does not clearly precede it.

Separation anxiety (Option C): Typically emerges around 8 to 9 months, peaks at 15 to 18 months, and diminishes by 2.5 to 3 years. It is closely tied to the early stages of object constancy and does not precede it clearly.

Stranger anxiety (Option D): Appears around 6 to 8 months, peaks by 10 to 12 months, and fades by around 18 months. Like separation anxiety, it develops closer to or alongside the early stages of object constancy.

Summary of Key Developmental Stages:

  • Freud's Oral Phase: 0-18 months
  • Piaget's Sensorimotor Stage: 0-2 years
  • Mahler's Subphases:
    • Normal Autism: 0-2 months
    • Symbiosis: 2-5 months
    • Differentiation: 5-10 months
    • Practising: 10-18 months
    • Rapprochement: 18-24 months
    • Object Constancy: 2-5 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the Topographical model of the mind proposed by Sigmund Freud?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ego and Superego are not limited to the unconscious-they also function at conscious and preconscious levels

Freud's Topographical model of the mind divides mental activity into three levels:

  • Conscious: Thoughts we are currently aware of.
  • Preconscious: Material that is not in awareness but can be readily brought to consciousness.
  • Unconscious: Thoughts, memories, and desires that are well below the surface of conscious awareness but still influence behaviour.

In contrast, Freud's later Structural model describes three components of personality:

  • Id: Entirely unconscious, operates on the pleasure principle.
  • Ego: Spans all three levels-conscious, preconscious, and unconscious; mediates between id and external reality
  • Superego: Also operates across all three levels; represents internalised moral standards.

choices.text: Consists of Id, Ego and Superego
Id works on the morality principle and guide a person on what not to do
Ego works on the reality principle
Defence mechanisms are a function of the ego to maintain balance between id and the superego

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the Structural model of the mind proposed by Sigmund Freud?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option B is false because it incorrectly states that the id operates on the morality principle. That function actually belongs to the superego.

The Structural model of the mind, developed by Freud, includes three components:

  • Id:
    • Operates entirely at the unconscious level
    • Functions based on the pleasure principle
    • Seeks immediate gratification of instinctual drives (e.g., hunger, sex, aggression)
    • Has no concern for morality or reality
  • Ego:
    • Operates at conscious, preconscious, and unconscious levels
    • Functions according to the reality principle
    • Mediates between the unrealistic demands of the id and the moralistic constraints of the superego
    • Uses defence mechanisms to reduce anxiety and maintain balance
  • Superego:
    • Functions at all three levels of consciousness
    • Operates on the morality principle
    • Represents internalised societal and parental standards
    • Guides a person on what is right and wrong

questions.text: Parents of a 2.5-year-old child frequently criticise and exert rigid control over many basic activities such as potty training, toy preferences, and food choices. This may hinder the child's development of autonomy and confidence, and instead foster feelings of shame and doubt. Which of the following disorders is postulated to arise from excessive rigid control at this developmental stage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to Erik Erikson's psychosocial theory, the second stage of development occurs between 18 months and 3 years of age and is characterised by the conflict of Autonomy vs. Shame and Doubt. This stage is crucial for the development of self-control, independence, and willpower.

  • When parents provide appropriate guidance and allow the child to make simple choices (e.g., what to eat, which toy to play with), the child develops a healthy sense of autonomy.
  • However, when excessive control, criticism, or punishment is imposed-especially during tasks like toilet training-the child may internalise shame and doubt about their abilities.

This conflict, when unresolved, can contribute to the later development of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD).

  • OCD is associated with rigid thinking, compulsive behaviours, and harsh internalised standards, which may reflect the overdevelopment of conscience and a lack of trust in one's autonomy, psychologically linked to this early stage.

Incorrect options explained:

Schizophrenia (Option A) is more strongly linked to genetic vulnerability and later developmental disturbances.

Addiction (Option C) often relates to issues in adolescence or later stages (e.g., identity vs. role confusion).

Conversion disorder (Option D) is associated with repressed emotional conflict, often in the context of hysteria, but not specifically tied to the autonomy stage.

choices.text: This is a normal phase of psychosexual development
This is known as the resolution of Oedipus complex
Penis envy is common in this stage
It operates at the unconscious level by repression

questions.text: A four-year-old boy develops erotic feelings for his mother and views his father as a rival. He fears his father might punish him by castrating him due to these feelings. To reduce this anxiety, he identifies with his father, adopting his behaviours and moral values. Through this identification, he begins to develop his superego. Which of the following statements is false in this boy's case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Penis envy is part of the Electra complex, which Freud described in females. It involves a girl's envy of male genitalia and desire for a penis, not applicable to boys. Hence, this statement is incorrect in this context.

This scenario illustrates Freuds Oedipus complex, which occurs during the phallic stage of psychosexual development (approximately 3-6 years of age).

Key elements include:

  • Erotic attachment to the opposite-sex parent
  • Rivalry and fear of punishment (castration anxiety) from the same-sex parent
  • Resolution through identification with the same-sex parent, leading to the development of the superego

Explanation of other options:

This is a normal phase of psychosexual development (Option A): True. The phallic stage is a normal developmental period in Freud's theory.

This is known as resolution of the Oedipus complex (Option B): True. The boy resolves his conflict by identifying with his father, which helps him internalize societal norms and develop his superego.

It operates at the unconscious level by repression (Option D): True. The entire Oedipus complex operates unconsciously, and repression is used to keep these unacceptable desires out of conscious awareness.

Explanation:

According to Freud's psychosexual theory of development, psychological disorders may arise from fixation at a specific stage due to unresolved conflicts:

  • A) Schizophrenia → Oral Stage (1)
    • Fixation in the oral stage (0-1.5 years), often due to disrupted early attachment or unmet dependency needs, is associated with regression in psychotic states like schizophrenia.
  • B) Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder → Anal Stage (2)
    • The anal stage (1.5-3 years) centers on control, order, and cleanliness. Excessive or harsh toilet training may lead to traits like rigidity and compulsiveness.
  • C) Substance Use Disorder → Oral Stage (1)
    • Addictive behaviors, especially involving oral gratification (smoking, drinking, overeating), are classically linked to oral fixation.
  • D) Conversion Disorder → Phallic Stage (3)
    • The phallic stage (3-6 years), involving complex psychosexual feelings (Oedipus/Electra complex), is associated with hysteria and somatization when conflicts are unresolved-hence, conversion disorder may stem from fixation here.
